verses.text: A good name is better than fine perfume, and the day of death is better than the day of birth.
verses.comment: A good reputation is highly valued, more lasting than material things. The reference to death exceeding birth points toward the value of a righteous life and hope beyond this world. The wisdom tradition points toward a life lived in holiness being crowned at death. This hints at the spiritual teachings on the value of a holy end.

verses.text: It is better to go to a house of mourning than to a house of feasting, for death is the end of every person, and the living should take it to heart.
verses.comment: Reflection on mortality brings wisdom. It is a call to consider the reality of death and judgment, urging that one lives life rightly. This connects to the Christian understanding of life as a preparation for eternity.

verses.text: Grief is better than laughter, for when a face is sad, the heart grows wise.
verses.comment: Sorrow often leads to deeper reflection and spiritual growth. Jesus' beatitude 'Blessed are those who mourn' echoes this spiritual truth. Suffering can be redemptive, purifying the heart.

verses.text: The heart of the wise is in the house of mourning, but the heart of fools is in the house of mirth.
verses.comment: The wise reckon with life's seriousness. Emphasizing preparation for one's end, it hints at the importance of repentance and virtue over temporary pleasures.

verses.text: It is better to listen to the rebuke of the wise than to listen to the song of fools.
verses.comment: Correction brings growth in virtue. Being open to guidance is necessary for maturity in faith.

verses.text: For as the crackling of thorns under a pot, so is the laughter of fools; this too is vanity.
verses.comment: Foolish pleasure is fleeting and empty, lacking substance—a lesson on pursuing what is lasting.

verses.text: Surely oppression makes a wise man foolish, and a bribe corrupts the heart.
verses.comment: This highlights how external pressures and corruption can undermine wisdom. It is a warning to maintain integrity.

verses.text: The end of a matter is better than its beginning, and patience is better than pride.
verses.comment: Endurance in faith is more valued than initial enthusiasm. Spiritual maturity comes with perseverance.

verses.text: Do not be quick in your spirit to become angry, for anger lodges in the heart of fools.
verses.comment: Anger is to be controlled. A disciplined mind aligns with the fruit of the Spirit (Gal. 5:22-23).

verses.text: Do not say, 'Why were the former days better than these?' For you do not inquire wisely about this.
verses.comment: Longing for the past can blind us to God’s work in the present. Trust in God's ongoing providence rather than nostalgia.

verses.text: Wisdom is as good as an inheritance, and profitable to those who see the sun.
verses.comment: Wisdom is as valuable as material wealth, guiding life under the sun (a recurring Ecclesiastes phrase meaning in this earthly existence).

verses.text: For wisdom is a defense like money is a defense, but the advantage of knowledge is that wisdom gives life to those who have it.
verses.comment: While wealth can protect, true wisdom leads to life, hinting at a spiritual sense beyond mere earthly gain.

verses.text: Consider the work of God: who can make straight what He has made crooked?
verses.comment: Humans should recognize their limits before God’s sovereignty. Divine will prevails over all.

verses.text: On the day of prosperity be joyful, and in the day of adversity consider: God has made the one as well as the other, so that man may not find out what will come after him.
verses.comment: Both good and bad times come from God. Trust in His providence is needed, pointing to humility and acceptance.

verses.text: In my vain life I have seen everything: righteous people perishing in their righteousness, and wicked people prolonging their lives in their wickedness.
verses.comment: Earthly success is not always tied to righteousness, a theme completed in Christ who also suffered though innocent.

verses.text: Do not be overly righteous, and do not make yourself too wise. Why should you destroy yourself?
verses.comment: Avoid self-righteousness and spiritual pride. Jesus warns about performing deeds to be seen by others.

verses.text: Do not be overly wicked, and do not be a fool. Why should you die before your time?
verses.comment: A call to avoid extremes: deliberate sin and reckless living lead to destruction.

verses.text: It is good to grasp the one thing, but also not let go of the other. For the one who fears God will come out from them all.
verses.comment: Fear of God keeps one in balanced wisdom, avoiding dangerous extremes. This verse points to the virtue of prudence.

verses.text: Wisdom gives more strength to the wise than ten rulers who are in a city.
verses.comment: Wisdom grants true security and effectiveness, even more than powerful leaders can.

verses.text: Surely there is not a righteous man on earth who does good and never sins.
verses.comment: This underlines the universality of sin, an essential foundation for understanding the need for redemption offered by Christ (see also Rom. 3:23).

verses.text: Do not take to heart all the words people say, lest you hear your servant cursing you.
verses.comment: Do not be oversensitive to the opinions of others; humility is the virtue here.

verses.text: For you know in your heart that many times you yourself have cursed others.
verses.comment: Humility and self-awareness are needed; we are all prone to failings.

verses.text: All this I have tested by wisdom; I said, 'I will be wise,' but it was far from me.
verses.comment: True wisdom is difficult to attain; humility before God’s mystery is the conclusion.

verses.text: That which is far off and deep, very deep—who can find it out?
verses.comment: God’s wisdom is beyond human understanding (cf. Rom. 11:33). Deep mysteries are revealed in God’s plan in Christ.

verses.text: I turned my heart to know, to investigate, and to seek wisdom and the scheme of things, and to know the wickedness of folly and the foolishness that is madness.
verses.comment: The pursuit of wisdom means learning to discern sin and foolishness. This process is lifelong and points to the need for continual conversion.

verses.text: And I find something more bitter than death: the woman whose heart is snares and nets, and whose hands are chains. He who pleases God will escape her, but the sinner will be caught by her.
verses.comment: This is a warning image against temptation, particularly sexual, as in Proverbs. The righteous are preserved through God's grace from the snares of sin.

verses.text: Behold, this is what I have found, says the Teacher, by adding one thing to another to find the sum—
verses.comment: The Teacher systematically seeks truth. Wisdom literature often builds from observation and meditation.

verses.text: which my soul has continually sought, but I have not found. One man among a thousand I found, but a woman among all these I have not found.
verses.comment: This difficult verse points to human frailty and the rarity of true virtue. It should not be read as a universal statement about men and women, but as a hyperbolic observation about the scarcity of righteous people.

verses.text: See, this alone I found, that God made mankind upright, but they have sought out many schemes.
verses.comment: Humanity was originally created good, but through their own devices, fell into sin. This anticipates later teachings on original sin and humankind's need for redemption through grace.
